abstract: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, believes that the government has become increasingly erratic and unfair in its treatment of the banks over the last few months, and he now has regrets about participating in the Troubled Asset Relief Program.
snippet: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, believes that the government has become increasingly erratic and unfair in its treatment of the banks over the last few months, and he now has regrets about participating in the Troubled Asset Re...
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, says he believes Washington has become increasingly erratic and unfair in its treatment of the banks over the last few months, and he now has some regrets about participating in the government’s Troubled Asset Relief Program.

headline.main: Dimon Decries Washington’s Treatment of Banks

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

abstract: Jamie Dimon, the chief of JPMorgan Chase, said he is in no hurry to raise the bank’s dividend due to an economy that he warned could still be threatened by a “double dip” scenario, Reuters reported.
snippet: Jamie Dimon, the chief of JPMorgan Chase, said he is in no hurry to raise the bank’s dividend due to an economy that he warned could still be threatened by a “double dip” scenario, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief of JPMorgan Chase, said he is in no hurry to raise the bank’s dividend because of an economy that he warned could still be threatened by a “double dip” recession, Reuters reported.
